channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Ingwar Perowanowitsch
item.description: In 🇩🇪 erheben wir eine CO2-Steuer von 30€, subventionieren aber jede Tonne CO2 weiterhin mit 100€, wollen die Autoabhängigkeit reduzieren, bauen aber neue Autobahnen und wollen mehr Menschen in die Deutsche Bahn locken, besteuern aber ihren Strom höher als das Kerosin der Lufthansa während wir ständig betonen, dass Deutschland das Klima ja nicht alleine retten könne.

item.title: Col
item.description: If you get a mouse infestation spray WD40 on them. It probably won't get rid of them but it stops them squeaking.

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @BorisBarbour @elduvelle @dhananjaythakur H&H is great. There’s also the Encyclopedia of Electronic Components vols 1-3 by Charles Platt from Make:Community which is a nice complement and helps you make the most of Digikey/Mouser etc.

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
How do we support the Katalin Karikó's?There's a lot of reasonable outrage today around how Katalin Karikó was treated throughout her career (full disclosure: by my employer, UPenn). Obviously a number of someones made a huge mistake by not recognizing the brilliance and potential of her work - no question there!What I've been thinking about and I'd love to get some scenius input on: how could we, as an academic community, do better?Here's one summary of what happened:
https://billypenn.com/2020/12/29/university-pennsylvania-covid-vaccine-mrna-kariko-demoted-biontech-pfizer/Taking seriously the notion that 1) we want to support the Katalin Karikó's, 2) high-risk, high-reward research takes time, and 3) everyone needs to go through a job evaluation at some point, here are a few ideas:*) Better support to help geniuses communicate (and fund) their ideas.
*) More funding for high-risk, high-reward projects
*) A longer evaluation period for individuals engaged in high-risk/high-reward researchWhat would you add/change?

item.title: Sheril Kirshenbaum
item.description: Very pleased to see NYT acknowledge Lise Meitner. Meitner developed the theory of nuclear fission & newly translated letters show she was barred from sharing credit for the Nobel Prize-winning discovery because she was Jewish & a woman. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/02/science/lise-meitner-fission-nobel.html?unlocked_article_code=JGbPgv1zYxrgU0vMDkmURf0UPTTjuLHgCJ7dTnWeFmWslaXwaWhZQ2CW6dr-HuF0MeGqXSfyQV0XyOgw7VTABLw9yJxUG8Jd9xQMrPqsNiNcVd3g1GwsxckwQMW5awE4g9aTqtT-TQbgs1PG5BpMDmUsqcAuapMB798_kyVYaEEXUwILTeojASGJ6ZvwXa5e-LpMvbl3o47_ZtX4JPzngzAvKys52S_L9v2O8h3vH0JYmLSlYmeokZCyl1NmKI_ZXmKyeExgLGB165ODtBkLtFvRRkCofN7uTN2imyfz20LJtbVEy1RdwZ6hqJZf8pvRMlD8yz-OjfYq7wLSbNw5k4zs0hAs&smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare #science #history #HistoryRemix

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: So this New Yörker article has a few very interesting items.1) A French woman driven out of academia, called Zoe Ziani, was instrumental in setting Data Colada onto both Gino and Ariely. All credit to her.2) The author got a file sent by the Hartford insurance company to Ariely, and it's nothing like the purported original data!3) The Duke investigation into Ariely has barely passed the triage stage. Is it possible to go more slowly?https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2023/10/09/they-studied-dishonesty-was-their-work-a-lie

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
Even if public Health is not caring that much nowadays, this result is relevant:
"In a highly immune adult population, median SARS-CoV-2 viral loads peaked around the fourth day of symptoms" https://academic.oup.com/cid/advance-article/doi/10.1093/cid/ciad582/7285011

item.title: Dorothy Bishop
item.description:
thread summarising yesterday's blogpost, re fraudulent articles from papermills. https://deevybee.blogspot.com/2023/10/spitting-out-ai-gobbledegook-sandwich.html
There has been a scandal at the publisher Hindawi that led to retraction of 1000s of papers.
In the past there was little motivation for publishers to act on such fraud, as they made a healthy profit from all articles, regardless of quality, & they'd accordingly expanded their operations massively, mainly through "special issues" with guest editors.

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: For all the folks hoping for optogenetics for chemistry Nobel: whom would you give it to? The folks who made the idea? Who found the molecules? Or the people who popularized them? The Nobel prize is no longer meaningful in the era of large collaborations and specialization.

item.title: addie
item.description: Continues to age like fine wine, like 15 years later

item.title: Kim Scheinberg
item.description:
@mekkaokereke
She knew how to take a parting shot:That morning at the lab, Kariko’s old boss had come to see her off. She did not tell him what a terrible mistake he was making in letting her leave. She didn’t gloat about her future at BioNTech [...] then a relative upstart in the field. Instead the woman who had bounced from dep't to dep't, with no tenure prospects and never earning over $60,000 a year, said with total confidence: “In the future, this lab will be a museum. Don’t touch it.”

item.title: Joanne Fisher
item.description: “The trouble is that we have a bad habit, encouraged by pedants and sophisticates, of considering happiness as something rather stupid. Only pain is intellectual, only evil interesting. This is the treason of the artist: a refusal to admit the banality of evil and the terrible boredom of pain.” —  Ursula K. Le GuinFrom the story The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas. #ursulakleguin #quote

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: @manlius @PessoaBrain @tiago @lmrocha @thilo @NicoleCRust @hirokisayama @WiringtheBrain Add teleology and things are easier no? A forest fire used by humans on purpose to move air may well be a machine in common language.

item.title: Fabrizio Musacchio
item.description: New book by Wei Ji Ma, @kordinglab and Daniel Goldreich: “#Bayesian Models of #Perception and Action – An Introduction”. “An accessible introduction to constructing and interpreting Bayesian models of perceptual #DecisionMaking and action.”🌏 https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262372824/bayesian-models-of-perception-and-action/#CompNeuro #ComputationalNeuroscience

item.title: @AllenNeuroLab
item.description: @kordinglab I was kinda hoping that someone would win the Nobel Prize for contextual fear conditioning since it’s taught us as much about the brain than anything else in the last few decades. So I’d go with Michael Fanselow.

item.title: Dan Goodman
item.description: @kordinglab I think I'd do the work for every paper I ever wrote differently, including the ones I'm writing up now. 😉

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Today I wrote about a new study on same-sex sexual behavior in mammals. It's evolved often, and looks like an adaptation to social living. Here's the story [gift link] https://tinyurl.com/ysj5wbzk
